Situation1: They send an occasional text to check in with their parents over the weekend.
Expectation2: Conduct daily prayers and religious services for the community
Situation2: Should attend the most significant religious holiday of the year, which draws the largest attendance.
Story: I stared at my phone, thumb hovering over the screen, rereading my stepmother’s message: “Will you call us this weekend? Dad misses you.” I knew what she meant—she wanted me to check in, to be present, to show I cared. I’d promised myself I’d do better, that I’d be the kind of stepchild who didn’t let weeks slip by in silence. But this weekend was different. The church was already buzzing with preparations for the most significant holiday of the year. As the priest, I was expected to lead the prayers, to be the calm center for hundreds of people seeking comfort and meaning. My congregation needed me, and I could feel the weight of their expectations pressing down. I wanted to be there for my family, to send that text, maybe even call, but every moment away from the church felt like a betrayal of my calling. My heart twisted as I tried to reconcile the two worlds, each demanding a piece of me I wasn’t sure I could give.
